transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: Hello! Thank you for having me. I'm glad to participate in this interview. I appreciate the opportunity to share my experiences. Please feel free to start with your questions.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Sure! As I mentioned, my name is Grace, and I’m 41 years old. I live in urban Los Angeles, and I work as an elementary school teacher. I really love my job and the chance to impact young lives. I’m married, and my husband and I are currently trying to conceive. We’ve been at it for a little while now, and it’s been quite a journey, especially after experiencing a miscarriage previously. 

In terms of my health, I make it a priority to stay active and eat well, but I do have some challenges, like dealing with chronic sinusitis and managing my weight. I have good healthcare coverage, which I’m grateful for, as it allows me to access the care I need. 

Overall, I feel like I have a supportive environment, but there are times when it can be stressful, especially with the whole conception process on top of my job and other responsibilities. How about you? What would you like to know next?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I first learned I was pregnant about a year ago. It was a very exciting moment for my husband and me because we had been trying for a while. However, shortly after finding out, I unfortunately experienced a miscarriage. It was a really emotional time for both of us, and it took a while to process everything. 

Since then, we've been trying again, and I've been focusing on taking care of my health. I've been taking prenatal vitamins for the past six months and trying to stay as healthy as possible, both physically and mentally. I’ve also been keeping an eye on my weight, as I know it can play a role in pregnancy. 

Can I share more about how I felt during that time or how I’m feeling now about the whole process?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I first sought prenatal care after I learned I was pregnant about a year ago. I was really excited and wanted to ensure that I was doing everything right for my health and the health of my baby. I made an appointment with my OB-GYN as soon as I could. 

The experience was a mix of excitement and nervousness. The staff was very welcoming, and they made me feel comfortable right away. They went over my medical history, and we talked about my previous miscarriage. I appreciated their sensitivity to my situation, which helped me feel more at ease. 

During the visit, they performed some routine tests and gave me a lot of information about what to expect during pregnancy, which was helpful. However, I felt overwhelmed at times with all the information. I remember leaving the office feeling optimistic, but also a little anxious about the journey ahead. 

Since my miscarriage, I haven't had the chance to seek prenatal care again, but I plan to do so as soon as I get a positive pregnancy test again. How about follow-up appointments? Do you think they are important for someone in my situation?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I was seeing a local OB-GYN for my prenatal care before my miscarriage. I really liked her; she was very compassionate and understanding. She took the time to listen to my concerns and answered all my questions, which made me feel supported during a very vulnerable time. I felt comfortable discussing my medical history and my worries about my previous miscarriage. 

Since I haven’t had a pregnancy since then, I haven’t been in touch with her recently. However, I do plan to resume care with her when I get pregnant again because I feel a strong rapport with her and trust her expertise. 

I think having a good relationship with a healthcare provider is crucial, especially when going through the ups and downs of trying to conceive. It can make a big difference in how supported and informed you feel. Have you come across any recommendations for how to maintain that relationship during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Persona: Before my miscarriage, I was scheduled for regular prenatal appointments every four to six weeks, which is standard during the first trimester. A typical visit would usually start with a check-in where the doctor would ask about how I was feeling, both physically and emotionally. They would measure my weight and check my blood pressure, which I found reassuring as it helped me keep track of my health.

After that, they would perform an ultrasound to monitor the baby's development, which was always an exciting moment to see the heartbeat and the growth. They would also conduct routine blood tests to check for any potential issues, and then there would be discussions about nutrition, exercise, and any concerns I had. 

Towards the end of each visit, my OB-GYN would take time to answer any questions I had, which I really appreciated. It felt like a partnership, and I left feeling more informed and hopeful each time. 

Since I haven’t had any recent visits, I’m curious about what the recommendations might be for someone like me who is trying to conceive again. How important is it to continue regular check-ins even when not currently pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I didn’t experience any significant health complications aside from the emotional challenges following the miscarriage. However, I do have chronic sinusitis, which can occasionally flare up, especially during allergy seasons in Los Angeles. Thankfully, it didn’t cause any major issues during my pregnancy, but I was concerned about how it might affect my health and the baby.

In addition, I’ve been mindful of my weight, as I know that my body mass index (BMI) is on the higher side, which can present its own challenges in pregnancy. I spoke with my OB-GYN about this during my visits, and she reassured me that it’s important to focus on a healthy lifestyle rather than just the numbers. 

Overall, I didn't have complications during my pregnancy, but the experience of the miscarriage did affect me emotionally, and I think that adds another layer of concern as we try again. How common are emotional impacts like that in women who experience miscarriage, and what resources do you recommend for support?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I’m currently taking prenatal vitamins, which I started about six months ago in preparation for pregnancy. They include folic acid, which I know is important for reducing the risk of neural tube defects, as well as other essential nutrients that support both my health and potential pregnancy. 

Other than that, I don’t take any regular medications. I try to manage my chronic sinusitis with lifestyle measures, like staying hydrated and avoiding allergens when possible, but I don’t have a prescription medication for that at the moment. 

If I do get pregnant again, I would definitely consult my OB-GYN about any additional supplements or medications I should consider. I want to ensure that I'm doing everything I can for a healthy pregnancy. How important is it to review medications and supplements with a healthcare provider before and during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I made a conscious effort to focus on my diet and nutrition. I wanted to make sure I was providing my body with the nutrients it needed to support a healthy pregnancy. I tried to eat a balanced diet that included plenty of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats. 

I was particularly mindful of including foods rich in folate, like leafy greens, beans, and fortified cereals, since I know how important that is for fetal development. I also tried to stay hydrated and limited my intake of processed foods and sugars, which can be tempting but aren’t as nutritious.

I made it a point to discuss my dietary choices with my OB-GYN during my visits. She provided me with resources and tips on meal planning and snacks that would be beneficial during pregnancy. I found that having a variety of healthy options not only helped me feel better physically but also eased some of my anxiety about gaining weight during pregnancy.

Since my miscarriage, I’ve continued to focus on healthy eating as I prepare for the next pregnancy. I think it’s essential to maintain a good relationship with food, especially since weight management is a concern for me. Do you have any recommendations for specific foods or dietary practices that could be particularly beneficial for someone in my situation?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I experienced a mix of emotions. Initially, I felt a lot of joy and excitement when I found out I was pregnant. I had been hopeful for a long time, and it felt like a dream come true. However, after the miscarriage, my emotional state changed significantly. I went through a period of sadness and grief, which was really tough for both me and my husband. 

I found myself feeling anxious about trying to conceive again, worrying about whether it would happen and if I could handle another loss. Sometimes I felt overwhelmed by the pressure of it all, balancing my job and the emotional weight of wanting to be a parent. 

Since then, I've been trying to focus on self-care and seeking support from my husband and friends. I find that talking about my feelings can really help, and I’ve been considering speaking with a counselor or joining a support group for women who have experienced miscarriage. 

Overall, I think it's important to acknowledge those emotions and not bottle them up. I’ve been working on being gentle with myself and recognizing that it's okay to feel what I feel. How common is it for women to go through such emotional ups and downs after a miscarriage, and what resources would you recommend for emotional support?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I have a supportive network that has been really helpful during this journey. My husband is my biggest cheerleader. He’s been incredibly understanding and patient with me, especially after the miscarriage. We try to communicate openly about our feelings and concerns, which I think strengthens our bond and helps us navigate this process together.

In addition to my husband, I have a couple of close friends who are also mothers. They’ve been a great source of advice and emotional support. I appreciate having people to talk to who understand the ups and downs of pregnancy and trying to conceive. They’ve shared their own experiences, which has been comforting and reassuring.

I also have a supportive family, particularly my parents, who are always there to listen and encourage me. They often check in on me to see how I’m doing, which means a lot. 

As I mentioned earlier, I’m considering seeking professional support, like a counselor or joining a support group for women who have experienced miscarriages. I think that could be beneficial for me, providing a space to share my feelings and connect with others who understand what I’m going through.

Overall, I feel lucky to have a solid support network, but I’m also aware that I might need additional resources as we continue this journey. Have you found that certain types of support are particularly effective for women in similar situations?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I have thought about my birth plan, even though I haven’t been pregnant since my miscarriage. I want to be prepared for when the opportunity arises again. Ideally, I would prefer to have a vaginal delivery if everything goes smoothly, as I believe that can be a more natural experience. However, I also understand that circumstances can change, and I want to remain open to whatever is best for me and the baby at the time.

I’ve read about the importance of having a supportive environment during labor, so I would want my husband with me throughout the process. I think having him there would provide comfort and reassurance. I also want to discuss pain management options with my OB-GYN ahead of time, as I want to be informed about what choices are available.

I plan to write down my preferences and discuss them during my prenatal visits, ensuring that my healthcare provider understands my wishes. I want to feel empowered and involved in the process, balancing my preferences with any necessary medical advice. 

I’ve also been considering things like the immediate post-delivery care for both me and the baby, such as skin-to-skin contact and breastfeeding, as I believe those moments are important for bonding.

In terms of preparation, I’m curious about any resources or classes you might recommend for expectant parents to help them develop a birth plan and understand the delivery process better. What advice do you have for someone in my situation as they prepare for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I've used a variety of sources to learn about pregnancy and childbirth. Initially, I started with books specifically focused on pregnancy and parenting, like “What to Expect When You're Expecting.” I found those to be really informative, covering everything from prenatal care to labor and delivery. 

Additionally, I’ve explored reputable websites, such as the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the Mayo Clinic. They provide evidence-based information that I trust. I also follow some pregnancy-related blogs and forums where other women share their experiences, which I find helpful for understanding what to expect emotionally and physically.

I’ve also attended a few webinars and virtual classes on maternal health, which have been great for learning about topics like prenatal nutrition, childbirth preparation, and breastfeeding. I think these classes can be really beneficial for connecting with experts and getting answers to my questions.

Lastly, I’ve leaned on my OB-GYN for information as well. I always feel comfortable asking her questions during my appointments, and she provides me with resources that are tailored to my specific situation.

Given your experience, do you have any specific recommendations for reliable sources of information or classes that can help guide someone through the pregnancy journey?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
Managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby has been something I've been thinking about a lot, especially given my previous experience. Since I have good healthcare coverage through my private insurance plan, I'm relieved that many of the costs related to prenatal care are covered. This allows me to focus on my health without the added stress of high medical bills.

However, I know there will be additional expenses as we move forward, such as prenatal vitamins, baby supplies, and eventually, hospital costs for delivery. I’ve started budgeting to account for these future expenses, and I’ve been researching the average costs associated with childbirth and newborn care. 

I've also been discussing our financial plans with my husband, as we want to ensure we’re on the same page. We’ve considered setting up a savings fund specifically for baby-related expenses, which could help ease the financial burden when the time comes. 

I’ve looked into local resources and programs that might assist expectant parents with financial planning or provide assistance with baby supplies, such as community organizations or nonprofit groups. 

Overall, while I feel relatively secure financially, I know there are still many unknowns ahead. I’m curious if you have any advice on financial planning for pregnancy and newborn care, or resources that could be particularly helpful for someone in my situation?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
During my first pregnancy, I was still actively teaching, and I was really excited about sharing my journey with my students and their families. However, I also found it challenging to balance my work responsibilities with the emotional and physical aspects of being pregnant, especially after the miscarriage. I was often worried about how I would manage my energy levels and the demands of my job while also prioritizing my health.

In the classroom, I felt a lot of pressure to maintain my usual level of engagement and enthusiasm, which can be exhausting. Thankfully, I have a supportive administration and colleagues who understand the importance of work-life balance. They were very accommodating when I needed to take breaks or manage my workload.

Since my miscarriage, I’ve been more mindful about how my mental and emotional health impacts my work. I’ve been considering how I would approach things differently if I were to get pregnant again—like possibly discussing my needs with my principal and making sure I have a support system in place at work.

I also think about how maternity leave would work, especially since I want to ensure a smooth transition for my students and my class. I’m curious about how other women in similar situations have navigated their work environments during pregnancy and what strategies they found helpful. Do you have any insights or advice on managing work-life balance during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
I have definitely thought about the postpartum period, and I know it will be a crucial time for both me and the baby. My plan is to focus on self-care and recovery after delivery, as I understand that the transition to motherhood can be overwhelming. I want to ensure that I give myself time to heal both physically and emotionally, especially after everything I've been through.

One of my priorities is to establish a support system for those first few weeks. I’ve talked to my husband about how important it is for him to be present and engaged during that time, and he’s fully on board. We’ve also discussed inviting family members to help out, whether that’s cooking meals, assisting with household chores, or simply providing emotional support.

I’m also planning to explore local resources, like postpartum support groups or classes, where I can connect with other new moms. I think it will be beneficial to share experiences and learn from one another during this adjustment period. Additionally, I want to look into resources for mental health support, as I know postpartum anxiety and depression can be significant challenges.

In terms of physical recovery, I plan to follow my OB-GYN's guidance on postpartum care and healing. I want to ensure that I take the time I need to recover, especially given my concerns about managing my weight and overall health.

I’m also thinking about how to balance my responsibilities as a new parent with my teaching job. I want to be prepared for maternity leave and have a plan for transitioning back to work when the time comes.

Overall, I’m feeling hopeful about the postpartum period, but I also recognize that it can be unpredictable. Do you have any recommendations for preparing for postpartum recovery or resources that could help new parents navigate this time?

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.
